texts.shortText:
Nemertines are soft-bodied, flattened, unsegmented worms that are best known for their ability to vary enormously in length. When observed alive they can become extremely elongated, but when collected or disturbed they contract and adopt a much shorter and thicker shape. The South African fauna is poorly studied and many species remain undescribed.

This species is best identified by its purplish to bright-red body colour and completely white head.
About 50 mm when contracted, but can extend to 20-30 cm or more when alive.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: About False Bay to East London.

Found under rocks and insinuated among sedentary animals on rocky shores. Moves around by gliding along on a bed of cilia, or by stretching out and extending the body through small gaps. Can be very hard to untangle and examine and often breaks if handled. There are no gills or other respiratory organs and gas exchange takes place across the extensive body surface.

All nemertines are predatory and shoot out an elongate proboscis from a special cavity just above the mouth to capture prey, which consists of other small invertebrates, such as polychaetes, bivalves or crustaceans. The specific feeding preferences of most South African species are not known.

Sexes are separate and eggs and sperm are shed into the water. Some species guard the eggs, but reproductive behaviour is not known for South African species. Can also regenerate broken pieces. In some species body fragmentation is routine and even broken sections from near the tail can re-grow full bodies.

Best recognized by colour pattern. A second member of the genus, Lineus ornatus, occurs in much the same region and has similar habits, but is dark blue-grey and has a white collar rather than an entirely white head.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 62)

Wheeler, JFG (1940). Some nemerteans from South Africa and a note on Lineus corrugatus M'Intosh. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 41(276), 20-49.
